This is a stylus made from Proto-pasta Conductive PLA.  The tip is made from conductive foam for IC storage/protection.

Printing is pretty straightforward, we used 45% infill and .2mm layer heights at 215C-230C temp, with a 50C heated bet.  Print vertically for best results, and print 2X in one print to help prevent the print from getting too soft.  
The tip is made from IC protective foam (available from Mouser, etc) and is just cut from a sheet with a razor or Xacto knife.  This gives the tip a nice soft, high surface area touch point making the stylus easy to use and accurate.

remixed_from.author: SLAM-ER
remixed_from.title: Solidoodle Cable Chain (Modified Nema bracket and round end)

description.text:
The files included are intended to be utilized with Claghorn's Open Cable Chain (thing:611593).  
SLAM-ER's Modified Nema Bracket (thing:114590), conversion links, and the round end mount where modified using Lawsy's original Solidoodle Cable Chain (thing:104817)  
Everything should be complete. I've printed it and installed it. If you need any help or anything to be altered for your specific printer let me know and I'll do my best to help you.
Update 2016-02-06: I put it all together and have been having great success printing, just never got around to updating. Sorry! I am using all 16 original links plus the two conversion links and it seems to run fine. I have noticed that the chain can cause problems if you have a print with a wall on the far left side of your print bed. So I just make sure I don't print close to the max x range of the bed and it's fine. Remember that if you're thinking about adding this mod. My print fan does the same thing to my y axis though so I've reduced my build volume by about an inch both ways just to be safe.

You'll need to print 2 of the single springs, one for each of the open conversion links.   
As of right now I have not fully tested if you need all 16 of the open cable chain links from Claghorn. I have printed off the group of 16 and after adding my conversion links and mounting the cable into the printer I'll find out if they are necessary or inhibiting in any way.  
I added a vertical version of the opened round mount in case anyone has trouble printing it on its side, but from what I've seen it may be better for strength if you can print it on its side.
Update 2016-02-06:I am using all 16 original links plus the two conversion links and it seems to run fine.

title: Fully 3D printable flashlight!  Made from Proto-pasta Conductive PLA

description.text: Fully 3D printable flashlight!  Made from Proto-pasta Conductive PLA.  Can be printed on a dual head or single head machine if filament is exchanged.

This flashlight is made from Proto-pasta conductive PLA and standard PLA. The base is standard PLA, the conductive part is conductive, and the top is standard. A small amount of support is modeled into the base so supports do not need to be turned on. The 9V battery clips into the flashlight after printing, and the LED's are inserted into small holes that can be melted or drilled into the conductive part after printing. The polarity if the LED's needs to be correct for this to work, and remember not to hook the LED directly to the 9V battery, this will fry it!! Use a few cm of your conductive filament or a 1-10K resistor. When done, the flexible section on the side is the switch, squeeze this down and the conductive parts make connection, turning on the flashlight. The Conductive PLA is a bit fragile, so the flashlight needs to be handled relatively carefully, but works great! Update 3/22/15 So we have had a few questions on this. First, this is intended to printed all at once, we had some folks wondering how to attach the 3 pieces. We printed it on a dual head printer with PLA in one head and Conductive in the other. The PLA fuses to the Conductive during printing, holding the assembly together. If you have a single head printer this is still possible to make, but you will need to switch out filament twice during the print. How exactly to do this depends on your slicer, but basically it pauses at a specified layer letting you change out filament. Second was a question on how to attache the LED. We have uploaded the LED datasheet (Cree C503B-WAN-CBADA152) which shows the lead size, we recommend about a 1/2mm hole and cutting the LED leads to about 8mm in length. The datasheet also shows the polarity, the shorter lead is (-) or the Cathode (also the flat spot on the epoxy package denotes the Cathode if you've already cut the leads). Third, how to use the filament for a resistor. This is pretty simple, the filament has a built in resistance. About 10cm of this (1.75mm diameter) filament has about 1.5Kohm of resistance which is enough to protect the LED from damage with a 9V battery. So just use about a 10cm piece of filament to hook the LED to the battery (only needed on one side) and you can figure out the polarity and experiment. It will not hurt the LED any to hook it up backwards, it just will not make light. Here is a quick introduction to LED's.
-An LED is a diode in a clear package, optimized to produce light.
-A diode is a semiconductor device that allows electricity to flow in one direction only, which is incredibly useful in electronics but not really the point of LED's.
-The amount of light produced is dependent on the amount of current flowing through the LED. If too much current flows, the LED will overheat and be destroyed, so a way of limiting that current is required and a resistor does the trick. The value of this resistor is picked so that about 20ma flows through the LED (the one sent with our product anyway) for full brightness, but quite a bit less than that will give nice bright light. You can use the equation V=IR where I is current and R is the resistance to calculate R. But there is a trick!!! There is a thing called forward voltage drop, or forward breakdown voltage Vf. For white LED's this tends to be around 3V, and it is the voltage that must be across the leads of the LED before any current flows. For these LED's, it is 3.2V. So, unless you have 3.2V or more you cannot light these LED's at all because no current will flow no matter how you hook them up. To calculate the resistance needed using V=IR, use the voltage across the RESISTOR. For example, if we use the 9V battery supplied, we know the total circuit voltage is 9V, and the drop across the LED is 3.2V, so the drop across the resistor is 5.8. So if you put in 5.8V=.020A*R, you get 5.8V/.020A=290ohm. Hope this helps!

title: Quantum Prusa Mendel - with iOS Assembly Instructions App!!!

description.text:
Quantum Victoria's Derivitave of the ever popular Prusa Mendel. Made to use 1.75mm filament, a JHead Extruder, and a modified Wade's accessible extruder, this printer takes everything that is great about the Prusa Mendel, and fixes a few problems including:
  • Z-Axis couplers that fall off,our design uses a double key on the Stepper motor to lock the couplings to the motors.
  • Filament guide to keep the fine 1.75mm filament on the hobbed section of the extruder bolt.
  • Much Improved Z-Axis homing endstop. It's not easy to knock out of adjustment now!
  • Stronger X Carriage Idler-End
  • Stronger rod clamps (Still need to be even stronger)

The Instructions are written into an App.
Grab a copy from the Apple sotre and get building!
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/quantum-prusa/id726713433?mt=8

remixed_from.author: TrevM
remixed_from.title: OpenSCAD ISO metric thread library / functions (updated)

title: Water container to tube, pipe or hose adapter

description.text:
Needed to try connecting a washing machine to a water canister for use without running water, although this form of a tube adapter is probably useful for many other situations. The sizes I used are for very specific combination, but decided to make it customizable for same effort. The larger base of the adapter is threaded on the inside, the thin pipe at the top is threaded on the outside. The thin pipe continues through the part to the ground, serving as both printing support and positioning a rubber ring if needed. It printed well for me in 0.1mm ABS without support, tried to print it solid with concentric paths, but I think Slic3r didn't make it wholly solid. The plastic doesn't seem to leak, but the threads on the water canister do leak, even with the rubber piece, so my thread parameters might be slightly off. As for the washing machine, the water pressure doesn't seem to be high enough, so it's back to the drawing board for me...
Main part of this job done by TrevM's ISO metric thread lib: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311031

The piece is designed to print without support. Do not try to make the bottom tube diameter so small that the support tube and rubber ring width won't fit within it, that won't work.  
It would be easy enough to modify the SCAD file to make the support tube disappear if the diameters are close to each other, and make a conical base support joining the tubes if the bottom tube is smaller than the top. However, that was not my intent when making this thing, my interests are very singular.  
The parameter names are shorthands, and are given in millimeters as usual. Diameters are thread diameters (diameter of the outside of the thread on the "bolt" basically), so that a M22x2 thread would translate to diameter 22, pitch 2. Rubber ring width is substracted from bigger tube thread radius. I think it's pretty snug fit if your measures are correct.  
Quality is number of segments the cylinders are divided to. Wall thickness and quality apply to each piece, though it would be trivial to allow specifying them separately for different pieces, I think that's more customization than is needed.  
In the sample default sizes, the top thread is M25x1 or one inch, and the bottom tube is M40x2, which seems to closely approximate the threads I was connecting. The 2mm thread pitch on the bottom tube causes the threads to also stand about 2mm out, which was far too much for the mouth of the canister I was attaching it to, so the lower piece thread depth is cut to 1mm max.  
However, even leaving just 4 millimeter groove for the rubber ring, the 4mm overhangs are terribly uneven, and don't appear to make a clean seal against the rubber ring. I'm thinking I might let little acetone soak up in the groove and hope it will dry up smooth. Acetone slurry might work somewhat too if you get a hollow piece with holes in it.  
Alternatively I might re-design it to stand on the lower tube with conical support extending up to the base of the wider tube at the top, serving also as a grip to screw it on and off. That would be challenging to print due to warping and getting it to stick to the printing surface.

comments.text:
http://www.thingiverse.com/ketil/about in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311031#comment-479186 suggested a different fix to thread_in_ring function, now that I read it I agree that's better and explains some of the weirdness I saw in the piece. It will get progressively weirder if the piece's wall-size is increased I guess. So if I end up playing with this more, I'll have to see if I can use that fix instead.
There's also room for adding a setting for in and/or outside thread (though supporting both at the same time needs some tricks with the lib), and alternatively some grip on the outside of the large pipe, so it can be screwed on and off a water container with ease. I'm also thinking of ways to make the support-cone in the middle without full fill, but I don't want hollow spaces for bacteria etc. inside either, and walls and rods wouldn't support whole perimeter. Maybe rods with arches between them, but they get progressively hard to render in SCAD.

A mini desk lamp powered by a 9v battery. Requires some simple wiring after the print is complete. Read assembly instructions before printing Things you will need:
  • Two 9V batteries
  • 5 LEDs, color is up to you
  • A foot or two of insulated wire
  • One rocker switch. The one I used was 1x1.5x1 inches
  • Two 9v Battery holders

PLEASE READ BEFORE PRINTING  
Step 1- Edit parts to your liking  
Step 2- Export and print parts. My lamp took about 19 hours to print all four parts at once at .1mm resolution with supports and rafts turned on  
Step 3- Remove prints from printer and post process. Clear away supports as much as possible  
Step 4- Solder 5 LEDs of any color in series. This means to wire the short leg of one LED to the longer leg of another LED. When finished, there should be one LED with an un-mated long leg and one LED with an un-mated short leg. These will be attached to the battery later  
Step 5- Solder insulated wires, about 8 inches long, to the two unmated LED legs. I used red wire for the long leg and white wire for the short leg.  
Step 7- Pull wires through the holes on the lamp cap, lamp neck, and lamp base. Leave the LEDs on the outside of the cap so they can be pushed through the holes in the head when the circuit is complete.  
Step 6- Attach 9v battery holder to cutout in the bottom of the lamp base, and pull the wires through the small hole to the cutout on the top of the base.  
Step 7- Solder the wire from the negative terminal of the battery holder to the wire coming from the short leg of the LED series  
Step 8- Solder a rocker switch in between the wire from the positive battery terminal to the wire from the long leg of the LED. This will give you a means to turn on and off the lamp without having to disconnect the battery. If you wish to skip this step, you can solder the remaining wire to the positive wire from the battery terminal. You will have to attach and detach the battery to turn on and off the lamp if you do so.  
Step 8- Attach switch to cutout in the base of the lamp. You will probably need to modify the dimensions of this cutout before printing your parts.  
Step 9- Test connection. Attach battery to holder and flip the switch. If the LEDs light up, you have succeeded!  
Step 10- Push LEDs through holes in the head of the lamp and use a heavy duty glue to glue all the pieces together. Allow time to dry.  
Congratulations, you have finished your mini LED desk lamp! Great job

This is a customizable version of my earlier String Puller Servo Horn with one big giant feature - the servo splines are built in! (See note at the end.) The downside to that of course is, you need a high resolution 3D printer to print it. (I have access to a Stratasys Dimension Elite with 0.178mm resolution at Drexel University.) The other downside is since the dimensions of the splines are an educated guess (made by staring at the stupid horns with calipers for many hours) they may or may not be a good match. Shout-out to Jhack for inspiring me to make it Customizer-friendly! Regarding the Splines:
So now that I've printed the part, I can say that the teeth don't really turn out. Probably because the printer resolution just really isn't there even on a Stratasys Dimension Elite. However, they worked "well enough" just by forcing them onto the metal servo spline. I would describe it as a kind of a press fit, except you can pop it off with a flat head screwdriver. My recommendation would be... try it! It worked well enough for me that I plan to continue manufacturing my horns this way.

title: Repaired my L printer with TR10x2 Z leveling threaded rods.

description.text:
Repaired my L printer with TR10x2 Z leveling threaded rods.
Originally my printer was equipped with M8 rods with extremely run-out errors.
Then I decided to use guiding rods with trapezoidal thread Tr10x2. The rods have small round-out errors.
The tricky point of this design is use a friction to fix the TR10x2 round nut. As you can see, there aren't any blocking pins, bolts, shapes for keeping nut in the place. Just friction between nut and printed body. Use a sand paper to smooth inner guide cylinder. The friction must allow to move the nut up and down (by spring force) but as big as not allow to round nut by threaded rods. It seems to be problematic, but believe me it is working perfectly.

title: Longer barrel(s) for 6 shooter elastic band gun

description.text:
Needed more power, so made longer barrel for this elastic band gun:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:603697/#files
print and use in place of the shorter barrel.

22-03-15
Added barrel coupler.
Slots over the end of your existing barrel and lets you extend the length by slotting another barrel into the other end.
For some super powered elastic band shooting. Print your barrels with at least 10% strong infill - otherwise they might well bend under the pressure !
I'd recommend 20% plus.
I printed the coupler with 3 layers and shells and 10% infill at 0.3mm resolution. Oh yeah and stand the coupler on end to print. And if you are daft enough to use it with the coupler and both barrels - be bloody careful loading small elastic bands. So far I've only loaded 2 at once. It starts getting scary past that point :-) Also added a short barrel specifically for use with the coupler. So you can have a variety of barrel lengths.
Also using the coupler and short barrel you can adjust the length of barrels in your slicer safe in the knowlege that the hole shape and size doesn't matter.
Basically lets you use ANY length barrel you want to without taking the gun apart to change barrels or having to design a new length barrel every time you need a different length..

Ultimaker with Twice the X,Y Build Envelope Keeping Z Standard

I have been working on building a larger Ultimaker as the one Supplied just isn't big enough.
I have been working from the Original REV 3 Ultimaker Laser Cut Drawings found http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13571
My Plan is to have a panel made at work consisting of 4mm Birch Ply with 1mm Aluminium Both Sides and then cut out on a CNC router with a 3mm cutter. On the DWG,DXF file you will see that I have started to put 1.5mm rounded internal corners which I will take a file to after. These should be cut out on the 15/04/2013 as my panel has been pressed. I then should be able to start the assembly of the case that weekend as I will have more time for finishing touches like rounding some of the edges off to help give it a better overall finish before taking it back to work to get sprayed.
I am not sure what to do with the base yet. I have been reading up on a lot of peopleÃ¢â¬â¢s comments, I am thinking of an Aluminium heated bed.
The side panels I am going to put a recess in for a Perspex panel.
I am going to purchase the Laser less Ultimaker Kit https://shop.ultimaker.com/en/ultimaker-kits/laserless-ultimaker-kit-new.html .
What will be different is the X,Y Rods and Belts keeping the more expensive parts standard. I will be asking Ultimaker when I come to purchase this kit, if they will supply those parts to me, to my dimensions at an additional cost. I am not looking for funding like someone else on here.
But I am after your knowledge, especially with regard to an inexpensive way for the base.

author: Berner747

description.text:
This clamp has no special purpose. It's the first part of a reading lamp that I'm designing. My design goals are:
  • no vitamins (i.e. completely printable except electrics/electronics)
  • easy printing (avoiding excessive overhangs, etc.)
  • easy assembly
    • Update: added the sketchup file Update 2013-04-30: Added stronger spring. Update 2013-05-15: Added teeth in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89457

Print each one of the left and right part with full infill. The spring should be one extrusion width wide, so each layer is printed in one continuous line for the most part. Slic3r tends to cut it into parts somehow, but I had no problems with the result either.
Maybe you will have to make the spring in a separate print, because it tends to come of the bed when the nozzle moves over to another part. I printed with a 0.5mm nozzle and an extrusion width of 0.55mm. If you have any problems using other settings, please tell me. When you're done printing, clean up the joint very thoroughly. Any bumps will avoid the clamp to open and close smoothly. After that, assemble the left and right part of the clamp by pushing the "male" part of the joint into the "female" part. You will need a slight amount of force for this. Then insert the spring as seen on the images and you're done.

It seems as if Cura has some problems with producing the gcode for the spring. v1.1 seems to produce better results, but still not as good as the same sliced wit slic3r 0.98. Please consider using another slicer for the spring if it shouldn't come out springy enough.

comments.text: I printed out 2 of these. They don't have a tight grip and they don't open up wide. Very cool though. It would be better if it had teeth instead of completely smooth. I can only print up to 0.4mm!

comments.text: I will see if I can make it this evening. Shouldn't be too big of a change. I don't recommend printing it in one piece, because the spring must already be under compression when the clamp is completely closed. Also, your slicer or printer might glue the pieces together during print which would prevent clean opening and closing. The clamp is pretty simple to assemble, so I don't see any advantage in printing it as a single piece.

comments.text: Oh good point about the spring compression, didn't think of that. I was mostly suggesting the single piece print because I've noticed designers get mad extra brownie points here on TV for single piece printed assemblies. author: bean710

description.text:
A stable up-right charging station for 3ds.
STL file is in mm.

I used an old USB charger (5V for Blackberry) to provide power. Positive terminal is towards the middle; negative towards the edge.
To couple the power, I used pieces from a ballpoint pen spring.
Works beautifully - you can easily pick up the device and place it in without having to fiddle with it - it starts charging immediately. NOTE: If you print in PLA, the holding tabs may break. This isn't a big problem as the stand is stable. Just get a gel sticky bumper, trim it down a bit lower and place at the other end to the charging pins. I have one I've used this way for a couple months now without issue.
A printable hacklab.to button. Drill necessary to make hole for pin on back.

Print face down. Drill hole through the back bumps. Put a pin through them.
Doing a multi-color print or filling the cracks with pain/colored epoxy/etc will improve contrast.

Fuly parametric Linear Bearing model
It already integrated size data for LM-8-UU & KB-12-WW bearings, you should be able to add other sizes easely by inputing the values provided by the vendor's data sheet. To be used in openscad assemblies, STL not included because there is no point in printing it.

title: Clifford The Master Double Perc Ice Chamber

description.text:
This is it, about as good as it gets, Version 5 Has been analyzed in ANSYS CFD (Computational fluid dynamics) for optimal drag free hits.
Percs have been enlarged from V1 and improved printing structure.
Snap rings have been made so pieces snap together, and will not separate without force.
Better tolerance with PLA printing.
About 40 hours of engineering have gone into the creation of this and your computer will suffer from the complex slicing required…. But once you have it printed, this is about as good as it gets. It’s big and impressive, bring it to parties….. But beware you may not understand how much you have taken in just because of how smooth it really is. Before use
1st Print Clifford
2nd print pdf instruction card for future reference To use
1st fill base with Ice water mix
2nd fill percs ½ full of water (too full and it makes too much drag)
3rd fill ice chamber and mouthpiece with ice Enjoy, takes a standard 14mm piece.
http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_sacat=0&_from=R40&_nkw=Glass+Bowl+14mm&_sop=15

PLA works best for this print
3 shells
0.20mm Layer height
10% Infill I used 210'C with 30'C build plate in 10'C garage with a fan on low to cool off the extruder. Going to need a well calibrated printer, but I have made 3 of them so far and they snapped together perfectly. Using a flash forge creator.

description.text:
This is a cover designed to snap onto the base of a player's miniatures in Zombicide.  If a player is controlling more than one hero character, their miniatures can be color coded by using the same color base covers.  
Zombicide is a modern board game that is often house ruled to suite the player's gaming preferences and customize the difficulty level of the game. If you have never heard of Zombicide and are not turned away by the zombie theme, you should certainly give Zombicide a try.  
My group often allows players to control two heroes at once.  These base covers come in handy for color coding which figures belong to which player.

This mode was created using Tinkercad.  
I used an Ultimaker2 printer, but you may need to make your own adjustments to the model if your printer produces different tolerances.  
USE CAUTION when attaching or removing the cover from your miniature, because some miniatures may break if you apply too much force.  If the cover does not fit your miniature's base the way you want it to, adjust the scale of the model to meet your needs.

Hello all you 3D wizards out there.  Here is your opportunity to defy gravity. Can your audience balance this Skyhook on the tip of their finger?  Well let them try!!! Then with the powers of your magical belt you defy gravity.  Drape belt over Skyhook while inserting it into the slot as shown in the picture. Shazam, the Skyhook will balance on the tip of your finger.  What fun when you amaze your audience of your powers.  
How does it work?  Think of it  like a rotating wheel where the belt is creating rotational force "torque" extending out to the tip of the Skyhook and the center of the wheel is the bottom of the Skyhook slot.  
Thanks for looking.

description.text:
These are the letest versions of my Quad feet posted by 12Hak (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:639582) Rounded bottom is to stop the feet digging into the ground and flipping the quad over if you don't land perfectly... or skid on the ground, in car parks for example. The Big leg provides about 40mm clearance and it suited to the 400-450 size quads.
The smaller one is 27mm tall and is best suited to the "mini" 200-250 size quads.

Best printed in Nylon, They are strong enough to hold the quad up but won't shatter in a crash or hard landing.
ABS is probably your next best option.

A sturdy, space-saving wall-mounted rack/shelf catered to hold light-weight bar stock. A 10-degree arm angle keeps cylindrical bar stock backed up against the wall, and a 25mm lip at the end helps to keep things from dropping over. Reinforcement holes cut into the support triangle also serve double duty to hold smaller-diameter bar stock, such as carbon fiber rods or piano wire (see photos for reference). Print more/less arms depending on the weight+length of your bar stock that you intend to hold up. Dimensions:
25mm (w) x 86mm (h) x 98mm (d)

Recommended settings:
  • Use ABS
  • STL has been sliced with 60% infill
    • How to mount:
    It is critical to sand the flat mounting surface to roughen it up, in preparation for the adhesive mount. You can use either 3M Command Strips, VHB, or any heavy-duty mounting tape. I used the large Command Strips and it has been holding well â€“ just make sure you clean all mounting surfaces with IPA and let dry before mounting. How much it can hold depends on the mounting used, YMMV!

Name: 40mm to 30mm Fan adapter.
Version: R1
Dimensions: 40.3mm x 40.3mm x 26.07mm
Status: Complete
Last Update: Jan 22, 2016 http://GabLabs.ca

Ive finally got around to updating this design. The previous design has obvious design flaws that would restrict airflow. I have changed to a plate to plate cone chamfer design, to promote better airflow and have also reduced mount plate thickness to cut down print times & material usage. I've made available 6 different sizes in this new revision.


**Printed with pillar supports


Changes:
- Plate to Plate cone chamfer design (better airflow)
- Removed Inner ridges (better airflow)
- Halved mount plate thickness (reduce print time/less material)

After multiple test prints, I've found it difficult to get a clean print due to unsupported over hangs, though i did manage to get a usable print. Additionally because of the design its difficult to mount the E3D v6 shroud as you lack space for your screw driver.


I will address these issues with a revision of the design soon.


Notes:
I designed this because I wanted more air flow to E3D V6 heat sink but didn't want to part with the injection molded shroud. So this bolts to it and allows you to mount a 40mm fan at the other end.


Next Revision will include:
- Thinner walls to maximize airflow
- Remove ridges on inside
- Thinner mount plates to reduce overall size

description.text:
EDIT: 6/16/16
I uploaded a new version of the idlers that support the roller bearing on both sides, so it won't bend towards the idler and stop rolling. Supports are built in, just cut them out after printing. Use TWO washers with this version. If things won't fit you may have to clean up the inside a bit with a Dremel tool or similar.

EDIT: Just wanted to give fair warning to anyone who is going to try this design, everything works fine, but there is no adjustment for the height of each extruder other than screwing the heat brake lower or higher on your cold end. That's really the only flaw I found and can be quite difficult to get both nozzles exactly the same height. In theory you wouldn't need to but nobody can print the parts flawlessly.
Just wanted to give you a heads up! See Bobkeyes comment about adding a grub screw to the extruder itself for a really good idea on how to make it adjustable. You'd need to tap a hole you drill into your cold end to do it though. But it's a great idea!
If you would like to work with the original SketchUp files you can download them here: http://ow.ly/UUDXx

description.header: This assembly uses all the same parts as this design, except the screws that hold it together might be different lengths, and some things you'll need two of, of course. Like the idler bearings for example, and the MK8 drive gears. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:760444
description.text:
UPDATE! So I installed the newest version of this on my Prusa i3 today. With the 4 linear bearings it's quite sturdy and prints well. I have not worked all the bugs in my software out yet and only printed with one extruder so far. (My thermal sensor on extruder 2 is not working properly. I think I broke a lead off while installing everything) Everything works well and it moves smoothly. Of course the real question is are the two nozzles level with each other. I'll post updates soon. This is my newly designed dual (or single) extruder for the E3D V6. I previously uploaded another model that was wide along the X-axis and thus wasted printable width on the printer.
This new version is only 63.5mm (2.5") wide and has the motors mounted facing lengthwise along the Y-axis so it doesn't waste print bed space, except for a small about in the Y direction equal to the distance between the two nozzles. I have NOT printed this out and tried it yet. I will be doing so in the coming week or two. This should work, but I have not tested it yet. If you print it out let me know how it works out! It's all 3mm screws of varying lengths. It uses the same toothed gear and bearings my other dual extruder uses. Look there for part info for now. I'll add a full guide and parts list here soon. Old dual extruder----http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:552748 If you have any recommendations or ideas please share them in the comments! EDIT1: I have been doing minor tweaks on the models, mostly to make screw heads fit better over the past couple days as I print the parts out. I will keep the files updated as I go but I'm pretty sure this is the final form now. 3-24-15 I will also be making a video tutorial on how to assemble this once I put a complete one together and figure out the easiest order to assemble it, and posting the link here. EDIT2: I added a hole in each x-carriage part becauese I noticed some stepper motors have longer shafts and the tip of the shaft prevented the motor form being screwed onto the rest of the assembly. The hole in the face of the clamping pieces allows the shaft to pass through instead of hitting. I also made it so the idlers can be lowered further allowing easier access to clean the toothed gear if it gets full of material flakes. 3-25-15 EDIT3: LOL ok I'm sorry for keeping changing the files so much. The differences are minor still. This version I added side holes to weave the wires from the extruders through and out the top center to reduce strain on the wires where they attach. I see there have been a lot of downloads. I'd love to hear any feedback anyone has on this assembly. EDIT4: Since this assembly is top heavy, I switched it to a 4 bearing X-carriage. I also tightened up the sockets the bearings sit in slightly so they are actually to spec in size. I had enlarged them to compensate for my printer but I realized that was a bad idea. The bearings should all fit snugly now. There are two versions of the X-carriage halves. They are identical except the space where the belt goes is 0.5mm tighter/looser between the two. if your printer tends to overextrude, or make holes smaller than they should be, use the "looser" version. If your parts come out perfect, use the "tighter" version.

This uses four LM8UU bearings and one or two MK8 toothed pulleys depending on how many extruders you put on it. All the screws are M3 but varying lengths. The four per motor that screw the motor onto the extruder face will probably have to be trimmed with a dremel or screw cutter. The threaded sockets on the face of the nema 17 motors are shared by the screws that hold the back of the motor casing on. I'd guess about 5mm threaded length on those screws.
You will also need an M5 screw, low profile nut, and a 5x10x4 ball bearing for each idler.
Order of assembly:
Insert your extruders into the base of the extruder face pieces.
Press on the retaining cap for each.
Screw the three M3 screws into the motors through the two seperate carriage pieces.
Screw the two M3 screws that go through the carriage pieces as well as the cold end caps, and into the extruder face. Fasten the other end of the screws with a nut.
Insert the three LM8UU bearings
Fit the half that has the belt retaining blocks to your printer belt
Press the two halves of the carriage together and run long M3 screws through the remaining holes to fasten it all together.
Install on printer. Note: You could place the whole assembly in two pieces directly onto your printer if you already had the three bearings on the smooth rods. This was part of my design. This way you can take the whole assembly off your printer without having to remove your smooth rods or take your printer partly apart. I will be editing this probably, and may be missing some steps. I wrote this without having printed the whole assembly yet. It's just how I am visualizing it for now. Good luck and lemme know how it works out!

comments.text: Amadon, At the end of the heat break that's inside the cooling fins there is a straight, untreaded section. comments.text: That's a really good idea!  you are talking about the smooth top of the heat brake right?  Yea I could see that working.  Kinda like how it works in the Chimera and Cyclops, except there are threads there.  Which is kinda cool actually.  More control instead of sliding it up and down by hand with heat sink compound making it want to jump further than you intended it to move.  you might lose some heat conduction between the heat brakes threads and the fins because they won't be cranked tight, but you could put heatsink compound on the threads before you start, and since it's threaded you still keep that fine control when you adjust it.  The only thing that might be a pain in the butt is keeping the hot end oriented a certain way if you're after aesthetics.  You'd have to loosen the nozzle, rotate the hot end, then tighten again.  You wouldn't have to use that for adjustments though.  Theoretically the nozzle would be the same height as before you rotated it, since it stops when it hits the bottom of the heat brake.

comments.text:
Awesome! If the bearings don't fit tightly you should put shims (slips of paper or something) around them or the whole thing will wiggle.
I plan on making this use 4 bearings to account for the top heaviness and also shrink the sockets for the bearings back down to spec size. I made them slightly larger to account for my printer printing holes smaller than they are on the model, but when I printed the x-carriage halves out it wiggled.
The two main hurdles I see with this design is it's top heavy so it needs tight stabilization, but at least the x-axis belt pulls perpendicular to the direction it wants to wiggle, and you can't really adjust the nozzle height unless you loosen the heat brake on your extruders. I have heard that some peoples nozzles are not identical even though they are both from E3D. Make sure yours are. Theoretically everything is identical on both sides of the assembly, but there can be slight variations in the printed parts.
comments.author: janwynen

comments.text:
No probably not. The only thing I changed the actual size of are I made the sockets for the bearings a little loser. I may change that back though later. The rest is just adding the holes on the sides to hold wires and making thing stronger. One tip. The nut on the back of the idlers might hit the thin part of the facebelt and facecap parts (the peice your motors screw to). I cut away that thin part including the fourth motor hole on the top by the idler so the nut wouldn't hit it. Since the rest of the face parts are so thick, and held by three screws there's no loss in strength. I'll probably upload edited ones today and a pic so you can see what I mean.
Depending on when you downloaded the stls there may be some holes you don't have on your print, but they can just be drilled in with a 3 mm drill.

description.text: This is a development board case for the Mikromedia Plus boards. I built it for http://www.mikroe.com/mikromedia/plus/stm32/ but I believe it will work for all the Mikromedia plus boards. It is meant for the main board plus the shield to allow access to the click boards on the back. Assembly is done screwing both boards into the case using 4-20 1/4" long plastite screws. I've included the solidworks files for modification if needed. Nothing holds the case together other than pin headers. This is intentional for prototyping. The main mikromedia board layouts are included in the solidworks file. This is helpful for making your own shield

This was printed on a DaVinci Pro 2.0 with supports. I printed at .3mm layers and 30% fill for speed but a nicer finish could be had with thinner layers screws used for assembly: http://www.mcmaster.com/#99461a282/=wev0ny

description.text: Update - 4/4/15 I have uploaded the new Little Mermaid pendant. I changed it so that lights are light and darks are dark. I also manually edited the picture for the lithophane to have enough contrast to carry through the details I wanted to show. This took a few iterations of editing, processing and printing. I think that it turned out great! My camera did not capture it very well though. I also decimated the image some so that it is easier to process for printing. There was much more detail there than was needed for this scale. Update - My daughter wore this to school the other day and when she came home, she asked if I could make a pendant for other princesses. When I said I could, she pulled out a handwritten list of all the girls in her class with the princesses and colors that each girl wants for their pendants. I had to laugh. So, now I have created one for Cinderella and am working on one for Belle. While working on test printing them, I realized that I have the polarity backwards on this one (lights are dark and darks are light) I also found that I could get better detail if I opened up the picture first and edited it some to create the definition needed for this small detail level. I will be posting an updated Little Mermaid later this week and others will follow and I will provide more detail on the steps I took to make them in case others want to try. End of update. My daughter wanted me to make her a Little Mermaid necklace, so I thought I would try making a tiny lithophane pendant. I used MakeALot's lithophane generator to create the lithophane: http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ Then I imported it into Tinkercad to cut out the circle, put a round rim on it and a loop for hanging it. I also created some custom support to help hold it upright for printing. See the instructions for tips on printing.

I found that it works best with a plastic that is mostly opaque.  Transparent plastic does not have enough light resistance to define darks very well, but it does create an interesting look.  On the other end, plastic that is too opaque requires a lot of light to see the picture.  I included a picture with my white plastic which is quite opaque, pink in the middle and light blue transparent for an example.  
I printed this in a vertical orientation because you get a much better resolution than you can with printing lithophanes flat.  
If your bed moves on one of the axis, make sure that the model is oriented lengthwise along that axis.  Mine moves along the Y axis which is why the model is oriented that way.  use a raft to help secure it to the bed since it is so skinny, we want to make sure that it does not tip at all.  
I printed this at a slow speed of about 40mm/sec at .15mm layer height.  I set the slicer to 8 perimeters.  The reason for setting the perimeters so high is because you want it to print with all perimeters and little to no zig-zag infill.  When you get a ways up in a skinny print like this, the quick zig-zag infill can shake the print loose a little, ruining the print.  
The support structure should break off cleanly and need very little cleanup.

There's already tons of Pen Holders on Thingiverse, but I wanted to have one with some organic touch to it.  
Thanks Thingiverse for featuring it on August 15, 2013!

This is a rather long print (12+ hours), with a large STL file (30MB Binary STL). Due to the long print time, I recommend printing it from SD card, rather than via USB. There is also a file penholder_reduced.stl. This should help those who had issues with slicing it. It contains the same penholder as the original, but at a somewhat reduced resolution. There is some overhangs and bridging within the thing, that should print just fine. Do not print with support, you will not get it out! The print in the picture used PLA filament from XYD (Chinese low-cost material at USD 22/kg), printed on a Rep2 at 220 degrees, Makerware 2.0 "MiracleGrue" slicer, 0.2mm layers, Sailfish 7.3 and 100mm/s. After the first few layers, I increased the speed to 150% Please note that after around 60% of the print, the whole print started to continue printing somewhat offset by 1-2mm. I don't really understand why this is, and I am also not the only one (see the Comments section!).

description.text: [2014-11-20] Try Prusa i3 Add-On X Tensioner instead! This is a simple adjustable belt tensioner that mounts on the top rod on the right end of the X gantry. See it in action...

For an adjustable tensioner you need to add a 624 bearing, a 4mm screw, and a 3mm screw to this part. It's designed for mounting on the top rod on the right end of the X gantry. Of course your x axis needs to be set up so the bottom span of the belt attaches to the x carriage. This tensioner will probably work fine inverted on the bottom rod too.  
The parametric SCAD file also allows you to print a non-adjustable part at your adjusted tension. A sample non-adjustable one is included in this Thing. You can also adjust other parameters, such as wall thickness, bearing screw size, etc.

title: Large Easter Egg - Seamleassly screws the two sides together
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Egg / Easter Egg designed in two parts that have a threaded joint to screw together almost seamlessly. At standard scale this prints to 7.5cm tall. Once printed just remove the raft and designed in support ring around the male thread and screw it together.  
Note: A "no support" version of the top part has been added due to some slicing apps having problems dealing with the fine designed in support structure.  
To add coloured bands pause the print several times and change to your choice of filament colours... the end result will be a brightly coloured Easter Egg. The coloured Easter Egg pictured uses Translucent Orange / Natural PLA / Translucent Blue.   
The support ring has been designed with a small amount of clearance so it should snap away reasonably easily. This has been tested to print well on a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicator.   
On a well set up machine this should screw together straight away with minimal binding on the thread. Screw it together and apart a couple of times should loosen any tight spots.   
Instructions: Use Raft / 0.20mm (Std. Resolution) / 3 - 4 Shells / 50% Infill (so the walls are strong) but no support as it has been designed in. Refer to the images to see the support ring that needs to be broken away o expose the underlying male thread.   
Note: File options are for both parts in one file or as the top lower and upper part separately (,,,which will provide greater freedom for colouring)  
If you like this take time to check out my other designs!

Use Raft / 0.20mm (Std. Resolution) / 3 - 4 Shells / 50% Infill (so the walls are strong) but no support as it has been designed in. Refer to the images to see the support ring that needs to be broken away o expose the underlying male thread.   
Add colour by pausing the print several times and changing filament colours.   
Note: File options are for both parts in one file or as the top lower and upper part separately (,,,which will provide greater freedom for colouring)

author: Romeo_ML

description.text: This is a parametric design for a centrifugal fan. I wanted one that could take a knock or two to blow air into my forge with, so I designed one with parametric wall thickness, fan clearance, diameter, height, output nozzle and inlet hole diameter etc. It can be printed entirely without support material and the two halves are held together with 3xNo.8 screws. The sample fan is 70mm in diameter and 45mm high. It uses a small 12V motor I salvaged, but can easily be modified (physically or programmatically) to suit a range of motors. The forge now has an RP'd 110mm diameter blower, and that blows plenty of air into the tuyere. The motor I chose does not have a very high RPM. It can only just reach white heat with one fan, but does not melt even in PLA due to the high airflow. A much faster motor on a smaller printed blower produces a higher flow, so I'm sure I can get more out of it later. If you want one with a handle on, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8096

Print case, impeller and lid. Attach motor to lid with 2 x M3 screws or similar. Warm motor shaft and insert into hole in base of impeller. Do not trim printing goo strands off the interior of the impeller. Ensure that: a) Impeller clears motor mounting screws, and
b) Impeller is fitted centrally on the motor shaft.
c) Impeller will rotate in the right direction to "brush" air out of the outlet. Fix the lid to the case with 3 x small countersunk woodscrews. Hook motor up to relevant volts. A nozzle may be made of any convenient tube or sheet metal and fixed to the outlet with duct tape. Hey, it's a ducted fan so this is a legitimate use.

comments.text:
What kind of machine did you salvage a high-speed 12V DC motor from? I've got a few DC motors out of old inkjet printers but they have quite odd power supplies like 35V, so I don't think I'd get much speed out of them without loads of batteries.
I have a large and medium-sized motor from a washing machine, but I think either of those would be over-kill for this, assuming they run on 12V. Going to use the larger one for a lathe project and not really sure what to do with the medium one yet.
comments.author: 4ndy

comments.text: I just melted bronze in the forge and cast it, using the 110mm fan and some charcoal. It works!
comments.author: vik

comments.text: how do you balance this rotor? I guess it would be pretty noisy if left unbalanced, and probably deliver less air/wear more.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: I balance it by hand, just manually turning the impeller round on the motor driveshaft and looking for wobble. As the heated driveshaft cools off, the plastic gets firmer and this makes minor corrections easier.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: Despite my continued protestations that PLA is somewhat fire resistant, I have no illusions that PLA will melt catastrophically.
comments.author: woofpickle

comments.text: I put the sample fan in front of the forge tuyere and cranked it over for a couple of hours on slow. I only just went to yellow heat. The blower's exit hole felt a little warm but was nowhere near melting. Given that there will be a thin metal tube giving it more distance from the tuyere, I doubt it's going to melt. Unless I really stoke the forge up and cut the power.
comments.author: woofpickle

comments.text: The aluminium would act as a heat sink wouldn't it?

comments.text: Well, sort of. Fortunately beer can is very thin and the air flow past it quite high, so it acts like a fan-cooled heatsink :)

My shower head bracket decided to give out and instead of buying a new shower head/bracket, I designed to design one that would fit over the existing one. I am not too sure how many other showers this may fit on, but if it has the similar bracket design it may work. This design uses 22mm M3 screws and M3 nuts as well. This is still a work in progress because some of the M3 nut holes are still a tad bit too small. Check out the timelapse here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7FEcv5PKnLY&feature=youtu.be Last picture in the set is showing what the broken original bracket used to look like. As you can see, my first solution to the problem did not work as the 3m tape would not hold the shower head. EDIT
In order to get this bracket to fit, you need to shave down the original piece that held the shower head. You can do this using a file and it should work fine.

title: Parametrizable any size to any size fan adapter with manifold tube angle

description.text:
TO GET A CORRECT DESIGN YOU HAVE TO MAKE SURE THAT YOU ENTER THE CORRECT VALUES FOR 'Ls fan1' and 'Ls fan2' FOR EVERY FAN SIZE, THEY ARE DIFFERENT AND ARE NOT STANDARD The code is written in openscad, if you use the 'Customizer' link on the right here are the variables you can change. The design only supports square framed fans with screws spaced evenly (in a square shape as well) ALL DISTANCES ARE IN mm
ALL ANGLES ARE IN DEGREES A- Essential variables T Wall : this is the thickness of all walls and fan mounts
D Fan1 : this is the diameter of the first fan
Ls Fan1 : this is the distance between mounting screws of the first fan
Ds Fan1 : this is the screw opening diameter of the first fan
D Fan2 : this is the diameter of the second fan
Ls Fan2 : this is the distance between mounting screws of the second fan
Ds Fan2 : this is the screw opening diameter of the second fan
L Mani1 : this is the distance between the smaller fan plate and the twisting manifold elbow
A Cone : cone angle for the second (the larger) fan
A Mani : this angle of the manifold tube twist, range from 0 to 180 degrees B - Advanced variables
Az Mani : allows manifold tube rotation around Z-axis, I may have a chance to do that next week C- Not commonly modified variables
N Pipe : this is a scale factor = diameter of the pipe/diameter of the fan, it's the same for both fans
$Fn : this is a resolution setting for all arcs and cylinders, means that a complete circle will have 50 segments, increase the number if you wish to get higher resolution curves at the expense of rendering time

description.text:
A rocket designed after a Fathers Day Card my daughter gave me. Simple retro design.  
EDIT: I have updated the model to enlarge the rivets, which get lost in a lot of prints due to printer resolution. It looks a bit better now.

This is a straightforward build, but there is one small thing: The three thin cylinders that print up from the fin apertures on the main body are to be snapped off. Those are there to help the cylinder, as it thins, to print better, as often thin things print a bit worse, since the layer below the current one hasn't had ample time to cool before the printer lays down the next layer, and that ends up smudging the print, I find. This way it prints better.

Wall Thickness Test - range 0.5mm to 5mm steps 0.5mm Results on Reprap Mendel / Pronterface
0.5 - didnt appear :-/
1.0 - tidy and accurate - good for thin walls
1.5 - tidy but undersize
2.0 - leaves gap along middle
2.5 - tidy and filled - good for higher walls
3.0 - leaves gap up middle
3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0 - all tidy ...and had real trouble with 5mm font :-\ I'm now using Slic3r so will try this again and see how it looks

This polyhedron can be folded from plane tiled by triangles.  All the triangles are congruent and there are 6 at each vertex.  The symmetry group of this is a dihedral group since the top looks different from the bottom.

title: Twintip symetric fins, 38.1mm or (1.5 inch for imperial USA) hole spacing.

description.text:
Built my first ever kiteboard and the other fins on here weren't quite to my taste. This one is mathematically designed and with a round leading edge. Google the "Coander effect" if you want to see why I didn't make the leading edge sharp. :-) Dimensions:137.2 long x 8.98 thick x 40mm deep. I'm only just learning kiteboarding, lots of on line research and I've windsurfed lots but I haven't rigged up and hit the water with a kite yet. See the instructions too, it's a big ask to 3D print plastic durable enough for stresses of real life use on a board like this!
Second part is a mould. Mirror image to get second half of mould!

If you can, print in nylon. I have (currently) an open delta printer and my dx.com nylon warps like crazy. Taulman bridge, low warp ABS or T-glass would probably work better. I'm going to try mine with some PLA first. "Collect" or "like" as I may make a mould design too and add to the files. Holes are designed for 3mm diameter, 25 mm deep. drill to proper 3mm thickness and tap with a "bottom tap" and some lube. Don't tap with a fast electric drill or you'll do more melting than threading! Back it off and clear it out of the hole a few times before the end as well, too much swarf will spoil the thread. To use the mould, print normally and then mirror image around x or y axis and then rotate around the same axis to place flat again. Ideally print in something like ninjaflex or harder and paint with PVA release agent. Place together (you may want to use holes to make a couple of wood hole templates) and clamp assembly together. If you've printed in something hard, tape the attachment holes and insert some fin screws ready to pour around. Fill the funnel with a medium polyurethane 2-part mix for a fast set, mix in some chopped fibres for a stronger piece. Low viscosity resins will help wetting out. Unscrew the screws after the fin has had plenty of time to set. Here's an example polyurethane, note the short pot life:
http://www.fibreglassshop.co.nz/collections/polyurethane-plastics/products/smooth-cast-300-polyurethane-plastic Let me know how you go!

Improved version - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:807105 This is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724526 I started using droidplanner with my APM 2.5 based quadcopter and needed a way to attach my phone to my transmitter. The mount is designed around my LG G2 in an Incipio case. Modify the clips for other applications. The clips hold an OTG cable which in turn holds a 3DR radio. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41536 The pieces were printed in PLA at .2 mm layer height and 100% density. The center mount piece is tapped with M3 threads. Printed pieces hold threads surprisingly well. M3x12 socket head screws hold the clips to the center piece. An M4x45 flat head screw holds the mount to the transmitter bracket. A nut secures the bolt to one side of the arm. The well in the thumb screw holds an M4 nut. JR9303_phone_bracket_2a.stl has a simple bracket with a shorter thumb screw. A single clip feels too flimsy for me but it may be fine for lighter devices.

A basic polarized battery holder designed to use the Keystone 1107-1 battery clip. I've used it for AA and lithium batteries such as the 18650 and 16340 but it can be easily setup for other battery with a diameter of a AA or larger. Features of the battery box:
  • mechanically prevents the negative side of the battery from contacting the positive terminal
  • alternating positive and negative terminals to shorten connections
  • positive and negative symbols are marked at the bottom of the battery slots to indicate battery direction
  • uses an inexpensive clip (the 1107-1 is less than $0.15 each in reasonable quantities)
    • If you change the values marked in the first few lines of the openSCAD file the number and size of the batteries in the holder can be customized. There are sample values for AA and couple sizes of lithium batteries in the comments of that file.

The Keystone 1107-1 clips insert in slots on both ends of each battery compartment (2 required per battery). The top end of the slots may need to be lightly cleaned up with a hobby or x-acto knife if the fit is too tight. Once inserted the clips cannot be removed but can be soldered in place. If you have some available, a light coat of flux on the solder tab from a flux pen helps with the joint. 22-gauge wire fits nicely through the holes in the ends of the solder tab although wire as large as 18 gauge will fit with some effort. I purchased the clips from Digi-Key.

Attach your PS4 console to the wall with this nearly invisible mounting bracket.  
V1. Individual Parts / Requires a large 300mm print bed  
V2. Plated Version / Only requires a small 150mm print bed

You can print this bracket out however you like, but please make sure the resulting part is strong enough to support the weight of your console.  I printed mine with Colorfabb XT Black filament using a layer height of 0.3mm, single shell, and 50% infill.  
When attaching your console to the wall take care to use proper mounting hardware. If you are attaching this bracket to drywall, paneling or other hollow walls your screws may loosen over time or pull out of the wall.  This can be avoided by using drywall or hollow wall anchors, which we HIGHLY recommend!

Copper grid in front with aluminium plates at the back side to produce an ion thrust with the use of high voltage. The distance between grid - plates can be changed. The hole on the side is to spy into a little bit (prototype) but also the enclosed version is uploaded My HV power supply (which is based on small 9V battery) does not have the strength to drive it good enough. Only kicking a candle light very slightly was not worth a video. The HV supply needs a discharge suppressor circuit or it ends up with arcing. first try: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XPtvzrtPkOA&feature=youtu.be Designed and build on a saturday and currently looking for a good HV circuit diagram...

comments.text:
How is this creating thrust? What materials (other than the 3D printed parts and a high voltage power supply) are you using to create thrust? Thanks in advance!
Sam,
comments.author: AstromechBuilder125

comments.text: At the inlet is a highly charged wires or sharp points, these points ionise air and it's attracted to the plates at the back which have an opposing charge. these ions then shoot quickly towards opposing charge to neutralize and then continue out some time after; the interesting thing though is this does not really produce thrust on its own, then the air is ripped to the back quickly it creates a loss of pressure in front of the inlet and high pressure at the exhaust, this is what makes the thrust.
comments.author: AstromechBuilder125

comments.text: More mystifying than magnets.
comments.author: beepbeep

comments.text: This looks like an interesting design, I look forward to seeing where it leads.
comments.author: Dragonwim

comments.text: As a POC / demonstration unit - why not have 2 on a pinwheel arm pointed in opposite directions balanced on a knitting needle. If you are able to deflect the flame of a candle, then 2 units in this configuration should be able to get the pinwheel spinning. If the arms bend down from the center such that the center of gravity is below the fulcrum, balancing is less of an issue. Make a place in the middle to place a piece of aluminum or other metal that you drill a round pocket into that the needle point presses into for minimum friction.
comments.author: ehud42

comments.text: I'm not sure this will work with my current power supply but i uploaded a short (very short) video so you can get an impression.
comments.author: ehud42

comments.text: Another thought (I know nothing of jet/rocket propulsion btw) - what about putting a nozzle on the exhaust port to funnel the exhaust gasses into a higher velocity stream?
comments.author: johann517

comments.text:
Of course this would be easy to do with the 3D printer. It's just i don't see any corona effect. Only little bit noise - it's very unsatisfying.
I really need a bigger HV supply to get some fun from it.
comments.author: ehud42

comments.text: Do you have pics / schematic of your power supply? I've been doing some unrelated playing around with electronics and deliberately used a 9V because it's internal resistance provided a convenient limited current power source. When I swapped the 9V with a 2 cell LiPo (7.8v), I destroyed the circuit (well - blew the soldered in fuse). So what I'm suggesting is, just feeding your HV circuit with a different voltage source might bump up the power...
comments.author: johann517

comments.text:
Ok, i tried today a flyback circuit. The power must be 10 times higher from this HV supply but the result of the ion thrust is minor.
From time to time it's possible to blow out the candle light - but only when getting lucky. After all it seems to be limited from the surface area. I might try to use a different design e.g. cone shaped or cylinder and nozzle the air as you suggested.
Many thanks for the idea :)
comments.author: ehud42

comments.text: That's pretty cool! You might be surprised! If the power supply can sit on the motor, I bet there's enough thrust that 2 of them working together could get the pin wheel spinning at probably a couple hundred RPM (might take a minute or 2 to get up to speed).
comments.author: johann517

comments.text: I have lots of experience with high voltages, Ive worked with flyback transformers and ignition coils. If you want high voltage without a lot of arcing I suggest using a CFL driver for a flyback http://www.instructables.com/id/MAKE-A-HIGH-VOLTAGE-SUPPLY-IN-5-MINUTES/?ALLSTEPS. Ive done it and I works pretty good as my desktoy. If you want large arcs, my largest are was from a ignition coil, the drivers are more difficult but its worth it. But it may melt this model

comments.author: haycurt

description.text:
I was pretty happy with the idea to have the filament spool at the back of my ultimaker but had a lot of spools that didn't fit on the original holder. I didn't want to use any other parts so i designed a full plastic printable one for spools with a diameter of down to 30mm.
The holder is sturdy enough to hold 2kg+ and has a tilt of 3° upwards so the spool doesn't slide down.
This is my first design on thingverse so feel free for recommendations.

Its pretty easy to print and install, you will need the "spool holder base" and the "spool holder 100mm" part at least. If you have a second spool, you can just ad the 40, 60 or 90 mm part to it.
I use it since a few months now and has no problems so far.
You might have to sand it a bit so the parts can connect, but not too much, they have to stay tight. I printed it in PLA with only 20% infill, 1,2mm walls and 0,15mm layer height and had 2kg on it. The strange shapes are for the sturdiness but if you want to try more weight, maybe a bit more infill would help. No brim, no support needed.
Most parts will work without support, just use at least 30mm/s print speed.
In the "base" part there is support for the hooks included.
You can remove it easily after printing.

comments.text: how it prevent the spool from fall from the holder ?
comments.author: kuiko

comments.text:
Oh, thanks for asking, i forgot to mention.
There is a 3° tilt upwards, so the spool slides automatically towards the printer.
Its not much, but its enough to hold the spool on the holder.
comments.author: kuiko

remixed_from.author: pablogil
remixed_from.title: 3DR - RepRapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller case

description.text: lcd holder for prusa mendel.

I am using 32mm /1.25inch tubes to hold my filament spools. I got some spools with 53mm/2inch inner diameter. With this hub adapter they fit perfect. There are some filament spool hub adapters but I can't find one to simply plug into the filament spool having the right size. So I made this Universal Spool Hub Adapter for the Customizer. You can not only change the dimensions, you can also define or remove the collar or chamfer if you want. There is automaticly a 1mm backlash added to the inner diameter to make it easy rotating on the axle/tube (Advanced Settings). On the outer diameter is also an extra mm added to fit it tight on the spool (I called it "Arm Compression" in the Customizer). I have uploaded the 25mm version for the original Prusa i3 HEPHESTOS holder. Many thanks to Runkel for making and testing it. After seeing fcartegnie clever parametrized remix I have added three new versions of the 25mm adapter with only 4 arms. There seems to be a rendering problem inside the Customizer, I can't find the reason. But the resulting STL files are perfect. Here are my other printer parts you may also interested:
http://www.thingiverse.com/wstein/collections/my-printer-parts

I used on PLA:
0.3mm layer thickness
25% infill

V1.4: inner hole fix (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1151473)
V1.3.1: Bug fixed for latest customizer
V1.3: Customizer creation failure fixed. Some smaller issues fixed. More slider used. License updated to CC BY-SA.
V1.2: part handling optimized
V1.1: new star shape

description.text:
Simple fixture to permanently mount a Garmin GPSMAP 400 series chartplotter to a bulkhead.  
A string can be attached between the cover (drill small hole in handle) and the fixture

printed with PLA 0.2mm layer height. I was unable to print this using ABS as layers separated during printing   
The fixture is mounted to the bulkhead using 4 screws and some sealant.  
The chartplotter itself is glued in place using sealent/adhesive (sikaflex).   
Five holes are required in the bulkhead, four for mounting the fixture and one for the connector/cable which protrudes on the aft side

title: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 Bowden filament guide Tube

description.text:
This Is My Bowden tube extruder pipe for a XYZ Da Vinci 1.0
I don't know if it is compatible with the 2.0, 1.0a or 1.0AiO as I do not own them. Refer to instructions for help Any questions?
Don't hesitate to ask

The adapter helps with smooth feeding of more exotic plastics. This Is a time consuming mod and you will need experience with basic hand tools. I TAKE NO RESPONSIBILITY IF YOU DESTROY THINGS TRYING TO INSTALL MY DESIGN You will Need
Roughly 80mm long piece 2mm ID x 4mm OD PTFE Teflon Tube
2x M3x12mm fixings.
4.0mm drill bit.
7mm drill bit.
3mm Drill bit.
Cable ties The Adapter holes will need a little drilling to make them a perfect fit. The optical filament will need to be relocated to allow room for this Mod.
I jammed a piece of filament with a few layers of kapton tape on it in the sensor to trick it.
Doing this will allow you to print with transparent filaments as well, so cup a tea happy days. The Adapter attaches to the plate with the stainless steal cone shaped pipe. The holes are already tapped to a 3mm thread. Obviously XYZ were planning something here. You will have to use M3x12mm fasteners. If larger ones are used the end of the fasteners will foul on the top of the feeder plate where it attaches. The stainless cone piece with need to be drilled out to 4.5mm to allow the bowden tube to be passed through it. Remember boys and girls when drilling stainless go slow, with a bit of pressure and plenty of Lube Wink Wink.
The end of the cone will come off when drilled, Don't worry it is supposed to do that. Depending on cooling fan shroud you use, it may foul of the carriage and need modding. The fan shroud will have to be put back after the extruder is re-fitted if you apply extra heat sinks to the aluminum heat break. I attached the heat sinks to the heartbreak with adhesive thermal compound. Next I am thinking of putting bowden down into the threaded stainless steal exctruder pipe for even smoother feeding

description.text:
This is a ported loudspeaker cabined design, tuned for a Cotswold Sound Systems BMR46XE N4R - 2.5inch - 4ohm driver. Material: 5mm plywood (LASER CUT)

  • 3D print the port and insert it in the port hole (fi = 34mm)
  • 4×M3 screws to attach the driver into the driver hole (fi = 68mm)
  • cables through the back hole (fi = 6mm)

Update: Have increased the size of the hole to 2mm diameter, with the bead still at 5mm diameter -> bead now prints perfectly for me at 100% My child's bear lost an eye and so, I needed a bead (~5mm in diameter, with a 1.5mm hole) - Scale up (or down) according to the size you need. N/B: My bead came out fine on my printer but the hole seems to have fused shut. You should get better results scaled up (or with a better printer) v2: 5mm diameter with 2mm diameter hole (may print better at 100%)

Finally I have finished this 1 year project.
what I came up with is a lightweight greyhound that you can control with an arduino and 8 servo's I bet there are better programmers out there that can make it walk even better and smoother. Also included is a basic program to get you going. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aDwTdbP_TBU

Updates:

  • 14-4-2013
    The Greyhound Programming stand
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73893

    14-4-2013
    Let me know If you have made a good program.
    than I can put it for download on this page with YOUR name on it.

    Things you need:

  • 1x arduino uno
  • 8x servo's (I used the cheap towerpro MG90s metal gears)
  • 1x (U)BEC regulator (I used a XQ 50 Pichler)
  • 1x Lipo accu (I used a 2s or a 3s)
  • 17x M3X10
  • 5x M3X30
  • 13x M3 NUT
  • Glue or you can plastic weld the pieces with the 3D printer.
  • Some wires and connectors (see scamatics)
  • I used a switch to cut-off the power from the servo's.
    • Assembly:

  • Download: Assembly The Greyhound.PDF

  • First of all glue or plastic weld the servo horns in the right places==>
    Be aware!!! of how to mount all the servo horns on the lower legs. see Assembly The Greyhound.PDF
  • Assemble the left body.
  • Assemble the front and back legs of the left side.
    For the correct assembly each servo needs to be around a certain angle. for detail look in the Assembly The Greyhound.PDF

  • Assemble the compleet left side.

  • Assemble the right side just like the left side accept for the the following parts:
    _Neck
    _HeadSpacer
    _BodySpacer35mm
    _BodySpacer31mm

  • Now that you have two halves it's easy to mount the arduino in and the rest of the cables see the picture for wiring.
    • Pin 1 Front Right Upperleg
    Pin 2 Front Right Lowerleg
    Pin 3 Front Left Upperleg
    Pin 4 Front Left Lowerleg
    Pin 5 Back Right Upperleg
    Pin 6 Back Right Lowerleg
    Pin 7 Back Left Upperleg
    Pin 8 Back Left Lowerleg
  • Mount it all together and your done.
    • to use the small programs I have written download the STAND.INO (For software calibration,this is the natural standing position.)
    And the WALK4.INO (For letting it walk, also in this program you need to fill in the natural stand you figured out in the STAND program. If you found a mistake please let me know.

  • I would love to see some programs and pictures of what you did.

  • Good luck!!!

title: Sortimo Insert Boxx for T-Boxx, L-Boxx and I-Boxx

description.text: This thing is a customisable insert for Sortimo T-Boxxes. You can choose the width and height of the boxx, including sizes Sortimo don't make, assuming your printer can print stuff that big! I created this as a template so I can have custom inserts to hold various tools in place. Please note that unless you extrude your own filament, you will be paying approximately the same amount to print these as it costs to buy them straight from Sortimo themselves. My primary purpose for this was to create sizes that I could not buy, also to create customised holders for different tools and objects that I don't want moving around in their cases. UPDATE: Uploaded premade stl's, and added an updated SCAD file that prints a little easier. It is less like the original on the base, but gives it a greater surface area, meaning less warping when printing in ABS.

Print the size boxx you would like and a set of pins, then glue them into the holes in the bottom of the boxx. (I used acetone, as i printed them with ABS) Depending on how well your printer is calibrated, you may need to clean up the inside of the holes, just grab a 4mm drill bit and spin it around inside the hole with your hand. Note: If you print larger boxxes with ABS they will warp. I have a bed which sticks things down quite well, and even then, on a 3x1 boxx, it tears itself off the bed about half way through.

title: XYZ Da Vinci Bowden filament tube holder guide

description.text:
This is my bowden tube holder for the Da Vinci 1.0 It works perfectly along side my Super Mega Delux fillament holder plus
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735303 I was sick of tangles so designed this simple bowden filament guide for the back of the printer The 2mm OD bowden tube keeps perfect tension on the filament as it leaves the spool and completely stops of tangles. you only want to use about 50mm of bowden tube. A longer tube may apply too much pressure to the filament and cause a belt slippage. This is by far the best mod I have done to my printer.
Tangles can and will ruin a 30 hr print 15 hrs in. Use super glue to fix the PTFE tube in the tube holder if necessary You will need
50mm piece of 2mm ID x 4mm OD PTFE tube
4mm drill Bit optional
130mm piece of 3mm ID x 4mm OD PTFE tube If you want to use the 3mm ID bowden tube to finish it off.
You will have to make a bit of a bell in the end of 3mm bowden and stretch the end of the 3mm over the 2mm ID bowden like in the picture. I then used duel some wall heat shrink to keep it from slipping off, like in the picture.
Doing this makes it really easy to feed the filament in to the printer housing You don't have to use M6 Bolts to attach the guide.

title: FIlament and Cable Guide for CTC / FlashForge / Duplicator / Replicator

description.text:
I had some trouble with my filament guides that were plopping out of the original plate. (Certainly the one where I had no filament inside !). I was inspired by the following design. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340031. I had only specific M8 Push-In Pneumatic connectors for 6mm tubes. So I had to modify the design.
But like always you just get an STL file that you can not easily modify it. I also added a small plate to close the opening to grip all the cables.
The pictures do not reflect my latest one that is mounted. I decided to place the fan cables beneath the plate. This is better for the cable harness.
N.B. : There are 34 mm between the 2 holes of the extruder ! My printer is a Flashforge Creator Dual

-Print it out
-Tab the holes for the M8 pneumatic connectors.
-Remove the filament on your printer
-Dismount the old plate
-Mount this one (Place well the fan cables in the guides)
-Use or not the closing plate
-Put a Ty-Rap around the cabling assembly to fix it well. That's it. Enjoy. You may use the *.123dx file to modify it to your needs in 123 Design.

description.text: I printed the MHDFS, but have no 608 bearings and did not wish to buy any... Overkill anyway: I have a 3D Printer! SO, using the power of 3D designing programs "Boolean Difference" aka "cutaway tool" I conjured up a press-in clip to custom make your own mounts for this spool holder! I may post another derivative of this with a hole in the middle for a shaft just like a 608 bearing... For now, I give you the 2 files I printed - one as a test and one in actual application (mounted on side of toolbox). Video of Printed Item: http://youtu.be/14a8W5HOV0s Enjoy!

Printed on a Printrbot Jr. in 1.75mm PLA using Repetier Host

210C Extruder Temp, 70C Bed Heat Temp, Use your favorite program to group/attach to a stand or hanger. Included file will work with some toolboxes/cardboard boxes etc. My test print responded well to a round file where it "clips" in, a flat file on the top and bottom of the circle and some 320 grit sandpaper throughout. Spins as smooth as can be!
