This is a rebuild of a project I hacked together with hot glue, bottle caps, and cardboard back in high school.  I used to take it babysitting and kids went wild.  
Stick a post it note to the top plate, tuck the corners in, attach the motor leads to a power source and switch and you're ready to paint!  
To build this, you need to print one of the spinner tops, a motor shaft coupling, and a motor mount.  
More details (part list, dimensions) in Instructions.

All parts print without support. My print:
FlashForge Creator Pro
ABS, 230C
Heated bed, Blue Tape Electronic Parts List
DC Motor (found in a box in the shop, could not find part no. online)
Batteries
Switch
Battery Holder (sometimes includes switch)
Wires My Build:
Nichibo 232022 DC Motor
4 AAA battery holder with switch (Radio Shack)
4 AAA batteries
2 jumper wires
6 x 6" board to attach motor mount
4 wood screws
Cardboard box to contain flying paint Motor Mount Dimensions:
ID: 1.13"
Height of motor holding section: 1.4" Shaft Coupling Dimensions:
ID: .13" Assembly:

  • Using Top_002, press the shaft coupling into the mating hole on the back of the spinning top piece. Add a drop of superglue if it isn't a press fit.

  • Attach jumpers to the two leads of the DC motor. Thread through the holes in the motor mount. Insert motor into motor mount housing. If there is significant clearance, wrap electrical tape around the motor until there is a snug fit. Extra vibration will make the assembly noisy.

  • If you are going to mount the motor mount to something (advised) do so now. You can tape it onto the bottom of a box, use screws, bolts, zip ties... again, more vibration will be noisier in use.

  • Once the motor is secure, press the shaft coupling onto the DC motor shaft. This should be a snug fit, as you want the coupling to move with the shaft.

  • Now that the spinner assembly is complete, run the wires out to your power and switch. Make sure this is far enough away from the spinner that you can turn it off without putting your hand in the path of the spinner. If you are containing the whole assembly in a box, it's nice to put the switch outside of the box.

  • If you haven't yet, put the assembly in a box or surround it with walls of newspaper. Paint flying off the spinner will paint a nice line on anything exposed in the vicinity.

  • If everything is secure, turn it on! The spinner should run without excessive vibration or noise. If it sounds terrible, make sure it's balanced and everything is secure.

  • When the spinner is off, load a sticky note into the top, turn it on (with hands clear) and drip paint onto the surface of the note. After I think I've done enough, I like to let it run for another 30 seconds to dry before I turn it off and remove the mini art.

title: Auto bed leveling for Greg's adapter

description.text:
Servo mount and Z probe for the Greg's Wade's geared extruder adapter.
Allows auto-leveling on your reprap.

This is designed to fit a Micro servo and a microswitch with regular screwholes. Used parts:
Tower Pro MG90S
Marquardt 1050.1202
3 M2.5 x 10 screws
1 M2.5 nut
1 M2.5 washer All holes should be sanded, but not to much to allow for friction-fitting the screws. Servo mounting plate should be mounted on the underside of the adapter, using the original extruder screw and a new M2.5 through the front fan mount. In you have a hotend similar to a J-head in length the Z-probe can swing 40 degrees backwards from extended position, allowing a cold end without an unsightly protruding raised probe. All firmware adjustments can be made similar to zennmaster's excellent guide

author: DEL_1979

title: Hulda Clark Zapper casing (for build your own zapper)

description.text:
Update 2015-03-24:
I added support for the PCB on the inside of the box. Please collect again! Might you be interested in the Hulda Clark science of health, than you definitely want to build yourself a Zapper. This thing is for a modified dual frequency zapper, that has a switch to choose between the 2 frequencies, after which the relevant leds will flash to indicate on which frequency you are zapping. Please LIKE before collecting Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

This thing is the casing only.
The featured picture is decoration only, please only print the separate files.
Print both bottom and lid, which assemble with 6 screws. You have to build the zapper electronics yourself
It does not matter if you make a PCB, or a spaghetti wire build, as long as you can fit all in the casing :-) I am still waiting for components, so I might change the design when my PCB is ready. The schematics are here:
http://paradevices.com/schematic.html The upper big hole is for the frequency switch, the lower hole is for the power push-button. The 4 little holes are for 2x 2 leds, that are driven by another 555 circuit , to reflect either of the chosen frequency switch positions. The schematic for the 2 flashing leds is here, as "railroad crossing signal". You have to either build 2 of those circuits, or drive different leds depending on the switch... it's up to yoy :-) The 2 handholds must be connected through 2 banana sockets in the front of the casing. I only provide he box :-)
Please LIKE before collecting Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

comments.text: I actually just finished building one last week. I'm not happy with how the case printed and was looking for another option. Have you used the zapper? I haven't tested mine yet.
comments.author: motorheadv10

comments.text:
For some years, we use a "Swing Zapper" from Meditech Europe. which is a 200 euro multi frequency zapper. We love it.
However, due to the cost and for 'give-a-way' I want to build a few simple versions. My PCB will be a switchable dual frequency version. total cost approx less than 10 euro. Maybe less effective than the Swing Version, but compliant to the Hulda specs, as long as you follow her guidelines :-)

title: parametric tool rack for keyhole shelving

description.text:
http://www.sodnpoo.com/posts.xml/parametric_tool_rack_for_keyhole_shelving.xml Based on Timmytool's scad file (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15515); configuring the keyhole dimensions is the same: key_big - diameter of the large round part of the key hole
key_small - diameter of the small offshoot from the main key cylinder
key_spacing - distance from one key hole to the same point in the next key hole
key_thickness - thickness of the material the key holes are cut from Additionally, to configure the shelf and holes: shelf_width - width of the 'shelf', centred around the keyhole
shelf_hole_radius - radius of the holes
num_holes - the number of holes The script will attempt to calculate the depth of the shelf and an even spacing between the holes.
